normalised: ## Film Festivals: More Than Just Popcorn and Celebrity Spotting, Yaar!

unnormalised: ## Film Festivals: More Than Just Popcorn and Celeb Spotting, Yaar!
normalised: Hey Bollywood buffs! Ever wondered what goes on *beyond* the red carpet glamour and perfectly posed pictures at film festivals? It's way more than just that, trust me. Imagine a giant mela, but instead of chaat stalls, it's all about movies, movies, and MORE movies!

unnormalised: Hey Bollywood buffs! Ever wondered what goes on *beyond* the red carpet glamour and perfectly posed pics at film festivals? It's way more than just that, trust me. Imagine a giant mela, but instead of chaat stalls, it's all about movies, movies, and MORE movies!
normalised: I just got back from a small indie film fest in Kochi, and honestly, my mind is blown. I saw movies I *never* would have found on N E T F L I X or in P V R. Short films, documentaries, animation... the variety was insane! It's like discovering hidden gems. Remember that feeling when you first watched "Dil Chahta Hai" and realised Bollywood could be, like, *actually* cool? That's the vibe, but multiplied by one hundred!

normalised: These festivals aren’t just for cinephiles with thick-rimmed glasses, though. It’s a great place to network! Aspiring filmmakers get a chance to meet industry veterans, get feedback on their work, and maybe even score some funding. Think of it as a giant "Indian Idol" for movies, but with slightly less drama and way more samosas.

normalised: The N F A I often has screenings and discussions at these events too, showcasing restored classics and providing valuable insights into Indian cinema's rich history. Plus, many festivals offer workshops and masterclasses. I even learned a thing or two about editing from a guy who worked on a Rajkumar Hirani film!

unnormalised: The National Film Archive of India (NFAI) often has screenings and discussions at these events too, showcasing restored classics and providing valuable insights into Indian cinema's rich history. Plus, many festivals offer workshops and masterclasses. I even learned a thing or two about editing from a guy who worked on a Rajkumar Hirani film!
normalised: So, next time you see news about the Goa Film Festival or some other event popping up, don't just shrug it off. Maybe check it out. You might just discover your new favourite director, a groundbreaking film that changes your perspective, or at least, get some amazing street food while celebrity spotting. Who knows? And yeah, don't forget to carry rupee five hundred for an auto ride cause getting a cab during these events is like finding a decent signal in a remote village in Bihar. Worth it though, one hundred percent! It’s usually around fifty kilometer from the airport. Think about it, you might just stumble upon the next big thing. Jai Hind!
